title: Documentaries about typography: what's next ?
content:
Hi !

I'm currently building a list of interesting documentaries about typography for a local design event.

While Hustwit's _Helvetica_ is a must-see gem, I realize most people have seen it. Adding it to my program would be okay, but I'm pretty sure there are other quality projects out there.

I already have a preliminary list, but I'd like to have the opinion of the Typophile community. I want to surprise my audience with new films and / or hard to find documentaries.

Any suggestions ?  
Have you heard of new films coming out soon ?

Thanks a lot in advance !

- -

(by the way, excuse my average english...)
author: cedilla

comments.content: _Pas du tout_, Jean-Francois. Your English is better than that of many native speakers on this site.
Check out this older thread: [Videos about typography](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/typophile.com/node/47979)

“Comic Sans – The Movie” would have been nice and fun, but I guess it’s not gonna happen…

Serious now: the BBC has broadcast a few documentaries and specials (as part of a culture program) about typographers or the graphic arts in general. I recorded a few of those. If you are interested in Stephen Fry’s take on the press used by Gutenberg or a short interview with Matthew Carter, contact me: mail [at] bertvanderveen [dot] nl.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO

Hi!

I had the same question a couple of weeks ago, and after some search I found [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.as8.it/edu/typography.html) from our typophile colleague Alessandro Segalini. I consider it quit complet and has at the bottom of the page a section on Film and Video.  
Hope that this help you...

António

Actually, there kind of is a [Comic Sans Documentary](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/vodpod.com/watch/1556283-comic-sans-documentary)…

I don't believe [Typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/typeface.kartemquin.com/) is available on DVD yet, but you can try and catch a screening.

Hi guys ! Thanks a lot for your suggestions. I'll check them out.

Do not hesitate to add more ! : )

Hi-

I remembered an old Flash-movie: "Behind the Typeface: Cooper Black" by Cheshire Dave.  
I did some Googling and found it here:

[http://www.veer.com/ideas/btt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.veer.com/ideas/btt/ "http://www.veer.com/ideas/btt/")

It also has a link to Cheshire Dave's site, where there might be more things like this.

Have fun.
Ah yes, I remember the Cooper Black movie. It's…different…

I saw a DVD about Frutiger, and another one about Eric Gill. but I couldnt get my hands on them, therefore couldnt watch them. but they do exist.

dr

[The Man of Black and White - Adrian Frutiger](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.linotype.com/98650/themanofblackandwhiteadrianfrutigerdvd-font.html)  
I watched it long back, and it was truly inspiring.

Thanks so much. More more more ! :)

By the way, check this out : [Rives at TED](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.ted.com/talks/rives_tells_a_story_of_mixed_emoticons.html)  
Most of us are not huge fans of ascii art, but it's still made with typography.

The Gill one I saw was a documentary by a guy who’s parents lived in the same village where Gill had his commune & consisted mostly of interviews with people who had secondhand recollections. Not much about type(design) in it.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO
Bert : I guess it was _Looking for Mr. Gill_.

_Not much about type(design) in it._

Bert, nearly 70 years after his death, Gill is remembered mostly for his type design and his, ahem, unconventional sexual inclinations. In his lifetime he was probably better known as a sculptor, and [described himself on his gravestone as a stone-carver](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/typophile.com/node/12115).

Yep, <cite>Looking for</cite> it was. And I know about Gill’s work outside of the realm of glyphs. A lot of that looks quite dated, while his Sans is still very fresh. What does that tell us about history?

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO

<cite> > I don’t believe Typeface is available on DVD yet, but you can try and catch a screening.</cite>

FWIW, the [Typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/typeface.kartemquin.com/) movie will be screened as this year's Wednesday night public event at [TypeCon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.typecon.com/) in Atlanta on 15 July ( [co-sponsored by AIGA Atlanta](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.aiga-atl.org/event.jsp?navigation=2&content=441)). The screening will be followed by a panel discussion with Jim Moran, David Shields, Nick Sherman, and John Downer.

AIGA Atlanta is selling tickets for general admission. TypeCon attendees are guaranteed a seat (if you check it off on your registration).

Some folks may remember that Justine Nagan gave a preview of some of the footage at last year's TypeCon in Buffalo. We're very excited to welcome her back to TypeCon to debut the finished documentary.

[The Art of Eric Gill](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.factualtv.com/documentary/The-Art-of-Eric-Gill)

Enjoy!
[The Art of Hermann Zapf](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.linotype.com/5667/theartofhermannzapf.html)

The documentary to see is Final Marks, from the 1970s –  
 [http://www.folkstreams.net/film,141](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.folkstreams.net/film,141 "http://www.folkstreams.net/film,141")

There is a short clip on YouTube, here – [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AasLZ-YFjs](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AasLZ-YFjs "http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AasLZ-YFjs")

Richard Kegler of [P22](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.p22.com/) is working on a documentary about Jim Rimmer and his amazing life and body of work. A trailer debuted at [TypeCon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.typecon.com/) in Buffalo last year. Can't wait for the finished product. Delicious somethings from the Pie Tree Press.

What about the video commissioned by Typophile or Punchcut? I remember Joe Pemberton had it on his blog. I loved that video.

Sharon
This is the one I'm thinking of. [http://typophile.com/node/45002](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/typophile.com/node/45002 "http://typophile.com/node/45002")

Aha! Found it at last...

Two years old – so not new and not a documentary either, but a typographic fairy tale called ["Little Yellow Writing Hood"](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/strangeattractors.com/LYWH.html) by Strange Attractors, and commissioned by Fontfont. Like the Cheshire Dave piece, it's different.

There is also a really nice piece of intro animation at [Out of Sorts Press](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018015747/http:/www.outofsortspress.com/letterpress/index.html) and further into their site, a video tutorial about the California job case. Enjoy.

Hey guys, thanks so much for your help !

Great community. Great suggestions.

!
